habitat: Grows in mycorrhizal association with trees, particularly hemlock, oak, spruce, and other conifers; can also be found in lawns and grassy areas under conifers; most abundant from June to October.
shortDescription: A large, edible mushroom with pores instead of gills, highly valued for its taste and texture, found worldwide under various trees.
benefitsOrToxicity: Good source of protein, fiber, copper, potassium, and vitamin B12; generally safe to eat.

identification.cap: 1.97 to 7.87 inches (5 to 20 cm) in diameter; initially hemispherical, later convex to flat-spread; pubescent then smooth; yellowish-brown to chestnut-brown or grayish-brown.
identification.stem: 1.97 to 7.87 inches (5 to 20 cm) high, 0.79 to 2.76 inches (2 to 7 cm) thick; initially bulbous, later club-shaped, longitudinally wrinkled; white, grayish, ocher, or light brown; solid and fleshy.

note: Difficult to cultivate due to mycorrhizal nature; can be eaten raw in small amounts when fresh but usually cooked or dried.
